Award.AwardTitle: Equipment Upgrade for Electron Microprobe, University of Houston Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sisson
0949400

This award provides $159,861 in NSF funding over 24 months to acquire wavelength and energy dispersion add-ons for an existing electron microprobe (EMP) at the University of Houston. Other upgrades (cathodoluminescence, upgraded crystal monochromator) are also requested to enhance the instrument?s performance. This instrument will be used for cathodoluminescence (CL)-imaging for zircon geochronology; garnet and other silicate zoning analysis using visualization capabilities; thermobarometry, geochronology and structural analysis (using X-ray mapping); phase characterization in relict mineral phases from mantle peridotites and basaltic glasses from the Arctic mid-ocean ridges and elsewhere; and retrograde eclogites, high-pressure jadeitites and their associated rocks from the Motagua suture zone, Guatemala. The instrument will be heavily involved in discovery through education. The facility expects to support over 80 undergraduate students per year, exposing them to modern microbeam materials characterization. The institution serves the minority communities in the East Texas regions, and is the top minority STEM graduate producer in a region. The enhanced microbeam analytical facility will help attract and retain high-quality graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior faculty. The PIs will be responsible for routine maintenance, training and scheduling - through an advisory committee.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electron Microprobe Upgrade, University of Houston

Microbeam x-ray spectroscopy using both wavelength and energy dispersion is a key and critical component of a young and growing geochemical group at the University of Houston. In 2009 the University acquired a used but still functional electron probe from the University of Tennessee, which was in need of a series of upgrades to enhance its performance and useability.  

Intellectual merit

The machine was upgraded  with new elemental and cathodoluminescence sensors along with new user interface electronics, data reduction software and a variety of other upgrades and repairs. The project was delayed by construction on the building housing the facility in 2012 and 2013. Major installation and testing was complete in 2013, and the machine has had nearly continuous uptime since then.

Current projects include phase characterization in relict mineral phases from mantle peridotites and basaltic glasses from the Arctic mid-ocean ridges and elsewhere; retrograde eclogites, high-pressure jadeitites and their associated rocks from the Motagua suture zone, Guatemala, among many other projects. The first papers from the new facility have been published in Lithos and the Lunar and Planetary Science Conference.

Broader Impacts

Enhancing discovery through education is one of the main uses of this electron probe. In particular, the new EDS facility is one of the keys to the high-quality hands-on knowledge transfer in an undergraduate setting. A high-quality EDS allows the rapid qualitative elemental characterization of minerals, in some cases materials that the students have been holding in their hands just seconds before, allowing a direct intellectual connection between macroscopic identification and the X-ray spectroscopic properties of minerals. 100+ undergraduate students per year have been exposed to modern methods of microbeam materials characterization in this facility, even during construction and renovation. 

This facility has achieved an excellent track record in its efforts to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics. The UH directly serves the minority communities in the East Texas regions, and is the #1 producer of minority STEM graduates in a region that includes many strong minority serving institutions, including Texas Southern, and UH Downtown. The strong initiative at the UH for the inclusion of undergraduates in scientific research projects and class work directly benefits from the funded upgrades. In addition, an enhanced microbeam analytical facility has improved our ability to attract and retain high-quality graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior faculty.
